title: Why should a start-up business use Agile development and marketing? - Quora

response.answer_text: Startups are agile by necessity. It’s not that they necessarily employ any particular flavor of agile, or have any prescribed processes (in fact, they almost certainly do not) but rather the part where there’s short bursts of work and regular assessment and prioritization. Somewhere along the line, many people forgot the Agile Manifesto, and they started focusing more on the processes and tools than the individuals and interactions. “Well, Scrum says we should use this tool, so that’s what we’re going to do.” That level of prescriptive “agile” is literally antithetical to the agile manifesto. The first freaking emphasis of it! But look at how startups do operate. There isn’t “we should do Scrum and be Agile!” But there’s a lot of “hey, since we’re remote, what way of tracking simultaneous work is best for you all?” See the individuals and interactions part of that? Working software is paramount. We have some feature that we want out, and we just need it out yesterday. I don’t know exactly what the perfect response to someone updating 3 different clients at once and then trying to make another change is, just get it to work in a reasonable way and get it out thee door, we don’t have time. Customer collaboration is so much more important than contract negotiation during the early phases. A lot of startup features wind up in there because someone at a company goes “ya know, we have like 10,000 people who do x, y, z, and it’d be sweet if a product did a, b, c to completely cut that out for us.” The last part of the manifesto is Responding to change over following a plan. Again, this is everything with a startup. It’s not shrink-wrapped software anymore. When OfferUp sees that they’re spending a fortune dealing with complaints over repeat offenders, they don’t go “fuck it, we have a plan!” No, they put in a rating system, so buyers and sellers can see “oh, this weird shady message is from a guy with 5 one-star ratings. No thanks.” And then no email to OfferUp. Don’t let the existence of agile flavors define agile. That’s really what this is. Look at the agile manifesto, and look separately how startups operate. There, you’ll find a ton of overlap. There are many methodologies which tag themselves as agile, but between poor implementation and potentially heavy amounts of process, we often see a team hold a few more meetings, call itself agile, and make a miserable team. Let us not forget that the word agile was chosen because it is to be able to move quickly and nimbly.

The bulk of the answers submitted thus far show a very strong bias that equates “start-up business” with “software development”. Which leads to additional biases toward undefined agile methods. This is unfortunate. While on-line businesses are incredibly easy to start, especially from a capital basis, and can definitely benefit from what agile approaches have to offer, Agile is neither a panacea nor the only method that should be used. There are many start-up businesses where the use of agile software development techniques as the primary organizing principles would be irreparably harmed. For example, a proprietor looking to start-up a local pizza shop has many important decisions to make that would suffer under an agile approach, particularly the potential negative impact on time and material expended prior to opening the doors. I’m not saying that certain aspects of a non-online start-up, particularly market development, might benefit from a short-cyle iterative approach, but only after traditional market analysis and demographic research have been performed and prior to capital being expended. Finally, the stats should be reviewed. Since the Agile Manifesto was published, the success rates for start-ups have not improved. This would suggest that while high profile companies (and individuals) who promote the use of agile everywhere, the reality is that it has not really moved the needle, despite widespread attempts.
